course_title: Physiology of Systems & Clinical Application to Speech Pathology Practice

learning_outcomes.description: Describe general and specialised physiology of the cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, sensory and motor nervous systems in healthy and aging populations as they relate to communication and swallowing.
Describe physiological causes basis of diseases in individuals with communication and swallowing disorders.
Apply knowledge of pathophysiology to describe the clinical presentation of individuals with communication and swallowing disorders and discuss pharmacological treatment options.
Apply techniques used in physiological experimentation, including hypothesis testing, methods of data collection and analysis, to evaluate experimental results.
Demonstrate collaborative learning skills and effective communication in a group setting.
Reflect effectively on your learning in physiology.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment 1A - Workshop Activities - Short Answer Questions
assessments.task_description:
We will offer twelve content-specific workshops throughout the semester to enhance your understanding of the course material. In each of these workshops, you will have assessment items. These are as follows:


Short Answer Questions

During the semester, we will have 9 workshops where you will engage in small group activities to answer short questions based on the course content. Each group's answers will be reviewed and marked during the class.

Important:

  • You must submit these answers individually on Blackboard after they are marked in class.
  • To contribute towards your final grade, you must submit at least 6 out of the 9 workshop assignments.
  • Completing and submitting at least 6 assignments will earn 12% of your total grade for this course.
  • Failure to submit at least 6 assignments will mean you receive 0%.

These are held in Weeks 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 8, 10, 11, 12.


Please ensure you bring a device with you that will allow you to upload your question to Blackboard.


Note: Week 1 is your introduction, and while there will be activities, these are not marked but designed to help you understand the workshop format.

More details will be provided during class and available on the Course Blackboard page.


What if I am unable to attend all six? We have given you a lot of notice to manage your time and attend these classes. However, if you cannot attend due to illness or other exceptional circumstances, please contact your Course Coordinator to discuss your options.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submissions for Short Answer Questions must be completed in class during workshops through TurnItIn.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
Module 1 and 2 Quiz 24/03/2025 4:00 pm

Module 3 and 4 Quiz 28/04/2025 4:00 pm

Module 5 and 6 Quiz 26/05/2025 4:00 pm
assessments.task_description:
In three of the workshops, you will be required to complete module quizzes which are designed to assess your understanding of course content.

  • The quizzes will occur:
  • Week 5: Covering Modules 1 & 2
  • Week 9: Covering Modules 3 & 4
  • Week 13: Covering Modules 5 & 6
  • Each quiz is worth 6%, totalling 18% of your final grade.
  • All quizzes must be completed individually.
  • Quizzes will be multiple-choice, label the diagram, and fill in the blank questions. No short-answer questions will be asked as you will complete these in Assessment 1A.
  • Quizzes will be conducted using Inspera. You are required to bring your laptop to class to participate.


Detailed instructions and additional information will be provided during the first workshop and via Blackboard announcements.

  • Please prepare for each quiz by bringing your laptop and reviewing the relevant modules beforehand.


Note: Week 1 is your introduction to the course, and while there will be activities, these are not marked but designed to help you understand the workshop format.

More details will be provided during class and available on the Course Blackboard page.


What if I am unable to attend all three? We have given you a lot of notice to manage your time and attend these classes. However, if you cannot attend due to illness or other exceptional circumstances, please contact your Course Coordinator to discuss your options.


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic, and complex. While students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require them to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students must demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submissions independent of AI tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: These quizzes will be completed in your workshops, using Inspera. Please ensure you bring your student card and your own device with you to class.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
For this assessment, you will receive a case study that outlines a client's health situation. Your main task is to analyse the details of the case and synthesise this information into a mind map.

The mind map should:

  • Clearly depict the client’s health conditions.
  • Demonstrate how different biological systems are interconnected in the client’s case.

Objectives:

  • This assessment is designed to enhance your understanding of the interactions between biological systems in health and disease contexts.
  • Mind maps will help retain complex details, foster critical thinking, and enhance collaborative learning.

Group Activity:

  • You will complete this task within a group setting.
  • Groups will be formed during your Masterclasses.


Peer Evaluation

As part of this assessment, a peer evaluation will account for 5% of your final mark. This evaluation will be conducted using Buddy Check on Blackboard, where you will assess your team members based on their ability to collaborate effectively throughout the assessment.

  • Completion Requirement: You must complete the peer evaluation to earn the 5% allocated to this component. Failure to complete the peer evaluation will result in a score of 0% for this part of the assessment, regardless of your participation.


Additional Support and Information:

  • Detailed information about this assessment will be provided during your Masterclasses.
  • Throughout the semester, sessions will be available to discuss any questions or concerns regarding this assessment with the course coordinator.


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students must demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submissions independent of AI tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your Assessment task, with the electronic coversheet available on the Schools website (under Undergraduate - Assessment), to Turnitin by the submission deadline.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The end-of-semester exam in this course is designed to assess your comprehensive understanding of the covered material.

Exam Format:

  • Type: Closed-book, on-campus exam using Inspera. You will need to bring your own laptop with you to the exam
  • Question Types: Multiple-choice, short-answer, label the images, fill in the blanks, and other assorted questions
  • Content Coverage: The exam will cover all lectures, practical material, and modules, with the focus proportional to the number of lectures in each module.


Attendance at modules, workshops, and practical classes is highly recommended, as there will be explicit questions on these sections in the exam.


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.


More details of the examination format will be provided on Blackboard during the semester.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The exam will be a closed book invigilated exam held on campus, undertaken via the Inspera eAssessment platform. Students will be required to bring a laptop to the exam that meets the device requirements for Inspera. It is important that you check before the exam that your laptop meets the device requirements for using the Inspera Assessment platform. If you do not own a suitable laptop, you can borrow one from the Library . The Library website Get familiar with Inspera provides the latest information for students about using Inspera. Further information about the exam will be provided on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Weekly Masterclasses

To maximise the benefits of the masterclasses, engaging with and working through your online modules to the best of your ability before attending is highly recommended. This preparation will enable you to actively participate, understand advanced concepts more clearly, and gain deeper insights from these sessions.

However, we recognise that keeping pace with the coursework can sometimes be challenging. If you find yourself falling behind, please don't be discouraged - attending the masterclasses will still be beneficial, as they will help you to catch up and clarify doubts.

Remember, while preparation is key to enhancing your learning experience, our masterclasses are designed to be inclusive and supportive, ensuring everyone gains valuable knowledge, regardless of their starting point.

Note: These classes are NOT lectures. Within these workshops, you will have activities to work through with your classmates to help you learn and/or consolidate your knowledge. You will also have an assessment in each (please see the assessment section). Your lecturers will facilitate these classes, allowing you some 1:1 time to discuss anything you are confused about.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 2(24 Feb - 09 Mar)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 1: Biological foundations & homeostasis

Module 1 of your UQExtend Online Learning aims to establish a strong foundation for understanding key concepts in speech pathology. It starts with defining physiology and its importance in this field, then explores chemical basics essential for biological functions. The focus then shifts to homeostasis, vital for bodily balance, encompassing negative and positive feedback mechanisms. We'll also examine cellular components, appreciating the complexity of organelles and how cells form tissues and organs. Concluding with an overview of major body systems, this module sets the stage for deeper, specialised discussions in subsequent modules, ensuring a comprehensive and integrated understanding for all students.

Associated workshops:

  • Week 1: Introduction to the course
  • Week 2: Module 1 Content
  • Week 3: Module 1 Content

We'll also examine cellular components, appreciating the complexity of organelles and how cells form tissues and organs. Concluding with an overview of major body systems, this module sets the stage for deeper, specialised discussions in subsequent modules, ensuring a comprehensive and integrated understanding for all students. Associated workshops: Week 1: Introduction to the course Week 2: Module 1 Content Week 3: Module 1 Content

learning_activities.topic:
Physiology Practical 1 - Osmosis

"Osmosis" practical demonstrates the mechanisms by which the fluids move within the body's compartments. This has important implications for how the body maintains fluid balance and the effect of introducing solutions (such as by intravenous injection) to the body.
This is completed on campus in the laboratory. Students are to remember to bring their PPE, lab coat, and closed-in shoes.
learning_activities.topic_description: Physiology Practical 1 - Osmosis "Osmosis" practical demonstrates the mechanisms by which the fluids move within the body's compartments. This has important implications for how the body maintains fluid balance and the effect of introducing solutions (such as by intravenous injection) to the body. This is completed on campus in the laboratory. Students are to remember to bring their PPE, lab coat, and closed-in shoes.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 3 To Week 4(10 Mar - 23 Mar)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 2: The Nervous and Muscular system

Module 2 of your UQExtend Online Learning focuses on the brain, spinal cord, and muscle physiology. Understanding these areas is crucial for treating conditions like stuttering or post-stroke communication issues stemming from nervous system dysfunctions. The module covers the basics of system-level understanding, including control of muscles and sensory feedback, and highlights neuro- and muscle physiology, which is important for speech pathology. It delves into motor and sensory systems and movement disorders.

Associated Workshops:

  • Week 4: Activities will cover Module 2.1
  • Week 5: Quiz or Module 1 & 2. Activities will cover Module 2.2

It delves into motor and sensory systems and movement disorders. Associated Workshops: Week 4: Activities will cover Module 2.1 Week 5: Quiz or Module 1 & 2. Activities will cover Module 2.2

learning_activities.topic:
Physiology Practical 2: Action Potential [Online]

The "Action Potential" practical features a computer-based module designed to showcase the electrical properties of nerves. This activity can be completed at the student's own pace but should be finished by the end of this week.
learning_activities.topic_description: Physiology Practical 2: Action Potential [Online] The "Action Potential" practical features a computer-based module designed to showcase the electrical properties of nerves. This activity can be completed at the student's own pace but should be finished by the end of this week.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 5 To Week 6(24 Mar - 06 Apr)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 3: The Cardiovascular system

This online learning module explores the cardiovascular system. It begins by examining how oxygenated blood is pumped by the heart throughout the body and how deoxygenated blood carrying carbon dioxide returns to the lungs for gas exchange. Emphasizing their interdependent relationship, the module covers the mechanics of cardiac conduction and contraction and the process of air intake, oxygen transport, and carbon dioxide expulsion. While these systems are initially taught separately, their overlapping functions are highlighted.

Associated Workshops:

  • Week 6: Quiz or Module 1 & 2. Activities will cover Module 3.1
  • Week 7: Activities will cover Module 3.2

While these systems are initially taught separately, their overlapping functions are highlighted. Associated Workshops: Week 6: Quiz or Module 1 & 2. Activities will cover Module 3.1 Week 7: Activities will cover Module 3.2

learning_activities.topic:
Physiology Practical 3 - Skeletal Muscle

The "Skeletal Muscle" practical further examines muscle contraction, investigating how the strength of muscle contractions is controlled.
This is completed on campus in the laboratory. Students are to remember to bring their PPE, lab coat, and closed-in shoes.
learning_activities.topic_description: Physiology Practical 3 - Skeletal Muscle The "Skeletal Muscle" practical further examines muscle contraction, investigating how the strength of muscle contractions is controlled. This is completed on campus in the laboratory. Students are to remember to bring their PPE, lab coat, and closed-in shoes.

learning_activities.topic:
Physiology Practical 6 - Blood pressure

The "Blood Pressure" practical examines the measurement of arterial blood pressure and the effect of posture and stress on Blood Pressure. You will also investigate the venous circulation and listen to the heart sounds.
This is completed on campus in the laboratory. Students are to remember to bring their PPE, lab coat, and closed-in shoes.

Students are to remember to bring their PPE, lab coat, and closed-in shoes.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 7 To Week 8(07 Apr - 20 Apr)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 4: Respiration and the process of speech

This online module focuses on the physiology of how we breathe, which is respiration. We will then relate this to articulation, resonation, and phonation in speech production.

Associated Workshops:

  • Week 8: Activities will cover Module 4.1
  • Week 9: Quiz or Module 3 & 4. Activities will cover Module 4.2
learning_activities.topic_title: Module 4: Respiration and the process of speech
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 4: Respiration and the process of speech This online module focuses on the physiology of how we breathe, which is respiration. We will then relate this to articulation, resonation, and phonation in speech production. Associated Workshops: Week 8: Activities will cover Module 4.1 Week 9: Quiz or Module 3 & 4. Activities will cover Module 4.2

learning_activities.topic:
Physiology Practical 4: Respiration [Online]

"Respiration" is an online clinical scenario based on a respiratory case.
This activity can be completed at the student's own pace but should be finished by the end of this week.
learning_activities.topic_description: Physiology Practical 4: Respiration [Online] "Respiration" is an online clinical scenario based on a respiratory case. This activity can be completed at the student's own pace but should be finished by the end of this week.

learning_activities.topic:
Physiology Practical 5 - Spirometry

"Spirometry" is a practical session focused on measuring lung volumes and airflow, along with exploring the factors affecting these measurements.
This is completed on campus in the laboratory. Students are to remember to bring their PPE, lab coat, and closed-in shoes.
learning_activities.topic_description: Physiology Practical 5 - Spirometry "Spirometry" is a practical session focused on measuring lung volumes and airflow, along with exploring the factors affecting these measurements. This is completed on campus in the laboratory. Students are to remember to bring their PPE, lab coat, and closed-in shoes.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 9 To Week 10(28 Apr - 11 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 5: The gastrointestinal system

In this online module, you will learn about the gastrointestinal system, including the essential processes of ingestion, swallowing, motility, and mechanical and chemical digestion.

Associated Workshops:

  • Week 10: No Masterclass due to Labour Day Public Holiday
  • Week 11: Activities will cover Module 6.1A
  • Week 12: Activities will cover Module 6.1A
learning_activities.topic_description: Module 5: The gastrointestinal system In this online module, you will learn about the gastrointestinal system, including the essential processes of ingestion, swallowing, motility, and mechanical and chemical digestion. Associated Workshops: Week 10: No Masterclass due to Labour Day Public Holiday Week 11: Activities will cover Module 6.1A Week 12: Activities will cover Module 6.1A

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 11 To Week 12(12 May - 25 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 6: Sensory Neurobiology, Mastication and Deglutition.

In sensory neurobiology students will explore sensory reception, with a focus on sensory systems that are highly relevant to speech pathology – the auditory, gustatory, and olfactory systems. Whilst in the second part of this module students will focus on mastication and swallowing in depth. The goal of this final module is for students to integrate previous knowledge in neuroanatomy and physiology to obtain an advanced understanding of body processes.

Associated Workshops:

  • Week 13: Quiz or Module 5 & 6. Activities will cover Module 6.2
